title: Quiz 1: Foundations, Wounds & Skin Infections
description: Assessment on basic nursing concepts, inflammation processes, wound healing stages, and skin infections.

questions.question: Match the Latin clinical sign of inflammation to its English description:
questions.explanation: The cardinal signs of inflammation are Rubor (Redness), Calor (Heat), Tumor (Swelling), Dolor (Pain), and Functio Laesa (Loss of Function).
questions.hint: Think about the root words: 'Calor' relates to calories/heat, 'Dolor' relates to suffering.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of wound healing in the correct chronological order:
questions.explanation: Healing moves from immediate clotting (Hemostasis), to cleaning (Inflammation), to rebuilding (Proliferation), and finally maturation (Remodeling).
questions.hint: The process starts with stopping blood flow and ends with long-term strengthening.

questions.question: A patient presents with a clean, surgical incision that has been sutured closed. Which type of healing is this?
questions.explanation: Primary intention occurs when wound edges are approximated (closed) with sutures or staples, minimizing tissue loss and scarring.
questions.hint: This type of healing occurs when the edges are brought together immediately.

questions.question: Review the clinical presentation below. Which factors suggest this patient is suffering from Cellulitis rather than a simple Abscess? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content:
Patient Assessment

A 45-year-old male presents with a swollen right lower leg. The area is diffuse, red, and warm to the touch. There is no fluctuating mass or central pustule. The redness appears to be spreading. He has a fever of 38.5Â°C.

options.text: Absence of a fluctuating mass/pus pocket

questions.explanation: Cellulitis is a diffuse infection of the dermis/subcutaneous tissue (spreading, no defined border), whereas an abscess is a localized collection of pus (fluctuating mass).
questions.hint: Cellulitis spreads 'across' the tissue, whereas an abscess is a 'contained' pocket.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a 'Systemic Factor' affecting wound healing?

options.text: Necrotic tissue in the wound bed

questions.explanation: Nutrition is a systemic factor affecting the whole body's ability to heal. Infection, necrotic tissue, and local oxygenation are local factors specific to the wound site.
questions.hint: Look for the factor that affects the entire body, not just the wound site.

questions.question: What is the specific medical term for the 'formation of new blood vessels' that occurs during the Proliferation phase of wound healing?
questions.explanation: Angiogenesis is the physiological process through which new blood vessels form from pre-existing vessels, essential for delivering nutrients to healing tissue.

questions.question: Which of the following are common causative agents for Cellulitis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The most common bacterial causes of cellulitis are Group A Streptococcus and Staphylococcus aureus. Candida is fungal, and Plasmodium is parasitic.
questions.hint: Think about the most common bacteria found on the skin.

questions.question: Acute inflammation is characterized by a long duration, tissue destruction, and fibrosis.
questions.explanation: This describes Chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation is short-term, self-limiting, and characterized by the cardinal signs (redness, heat, swelling, pain).
questions.hint: Think about the difference between a sudden injury vs. a long-term disease like arthritis.

questions.question: Match the disease classification to its correct example:
questions.hint: Noso- relates to hospital, Idio- relates to self/unknown.

questions.question: The primary treatment for a skin abscess involving a localized collection of pus is ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Antibiotics alone are often insufficient for abscesses; the pus must be mechanically drained via Incision and Drainage (I&D) to allow healing.
questions.hint: A surgical procedure to release the pus.
